author: oaklandmatt
content:
I have a different angle you could try. I would focus almost all your energy on becoming a better, more truthful, richer lyricist. That's the only place you'll be original because there's only one you. Paradoxically, it's also the way you'll write songs that have a universal appeal because the more personal you get, the more the underlying universal emotions will resonate with people.

Trying to be analytical about melodies and structure and style when writing has never yielded good songs for me or literally anyone I know. All the best songwriters I've met write all their best songs lyrics first.

Also, when you have something to say, it's surprising how little you pay attention to the melody. The melodies and structural components seem to just come when your heart is already in the story.

The only other thing I'd say is learn A+ songs. Learn the lyrics completely and learn the story behind them as much as possible. Then learn to sing them the way the original version is sung. That will expand your vocabulary as a vocalist and reinforce great lyrics.

Lastly, technology is going to continue to increasingly replace stylistic innovation. Yeah AI blah blah blah, but already drum machines and synth presets and splice and DAWs. The last thing to be replaced will be you personally writing things from your experience. Songs about your deepest insecurities and songs about your pet gerbil both fall into this category. Explore all of it.

author: Will Melones
content:
I’m sure we all share this struggle to some degree. I’ve got some projects that I’ve put many hours into, just to let them sit on a hard drive for years.

Co-writing has helped a lot, and has taken some ideas to places I never would have thought to go. The feeling that you have some moral obligation to your collaborators to finish is motivating. When you’re making art for yourself, it doesn’t benefit from those positive forces of peer pressure, and there’s a lack of constraints and no sense of urgency. 

I think making creative decisions is metabolically expensive. It’s easier to defer all decisions, which is why you see DAW-age producers committing to so little until the mix. In the same way you can defer the entire songwriting process, especially if you have someone else’s project or deadline to prioritize over your own.

To be both the creative mind and the executive finisher is a lot of exhausting context switching. Some options might be to split these responsibilities with someone else, or to dedicate separate time to each task. If someone hires me to print stems or solder a patchbay, the last thing I want to do is engage in creativity. But when I get inspired to write, I don’t want to stop and troubleshoot the plug-in that’s crashing the session.

Maybe like the divergence/convergence approach would be to set aside an hour or three at the end of your day to finish ideas you’ve already got brewing—set a timer and finish a song, or a verse. Or, even better yet, dedicate the *end* of your day to play and experimentation. Then the next morning, hopefully with fresh perspective, get in the mood to tie up loose ends and prepare your next steps. You’ve demonstrated that you’re good at wearing that hat for other artists, so you can do it for your songs, too. Just maybe not while you’re in the creative flow.

I’m not practicing what I preach, just brain-dumping. I definitely don’t have this figured out.

author: Rob Domos
content:
His stance against slant rhymes seems to be more about being in favor of things fitting very tightly together and having intentionality and form and structure. He and another friend of mine viewed slant rhymes as mostly a product of laziness, as if the writer couldn’t be bothered to find something that truly fit.  

I countered referencing the hook to an Olivia Rodrigo song where every single rhyme is a slant rhyme, which IMO adds to the value of it because she’s trying to express how things don’t quite fit and how the thoughts in her mind are unresolved, and the rhyme scheme should reflect that to create a unified feeling. 

The lyrics are:

You’ve got me thinking
That two plus two equals five 
And I’m the love of your life 
Cause if rain don’t fall and sun don’t shine 
Then changing you is possible 
No, Love is never logical 

Here she’s searching and grasping. She’s unresolved. She literally uses a metaphor of the math not adding up. Why would we then make the math add up phonetically? It would weaken the effect. 

Alan was meh on it. 

I also argued that hard rhymes can be like the phonetic equivalent of a classical Haydn V-I movement that has very little color or tension, and that slight rhymes can be like jazz chords and that adding a 7 and a sharp 11 on top of the tonic chord doesn’t mean you “failed to resolve”. Someone else at the table was like “well show me a truly great song built on slant rhymes and we’ll see. I’m open to it” and in my head I was like “I thought I just did” but they didn’t love it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Hmmm. Fun challenge. So both of these songs seem to be pretty heavy on evocative or surrealistic imagery without an obvious central subject (if there is one at all).

How about this idea: For each section of your song pull up a movie scene that you know or enjoy. Then write down everything you see without explicitly giving away what movie scene it is. Describe everything. Pick out details. Whether their actually represented in the scene or you're just speculating on something that *could* be. Or make up descriptions of the scenario beyond what's actually spelled out:

*Two people casting glances across the room. One doesn't notice*
*Hard shadows stretched across the floor*
*Does he have enough cash in his wallet?*
*Somebody's running late*
*The room is thick with tension*
*Someone did the crime*

I dunno. I'm just spitballing, here.

OR start mashing concepts together. Things that don't normally co-exist. You're bound to get some evocative results. Cedric from *The Mars Volta* fits into this mode pretty well. His lyrics are extremely evocative but after all these years I still can't say for sure what they're actually saying. If there's a coherent thought in his songs it's so far obfuscated that you'd never know anyways.

author: Brian Reynolds
content:
I'm always in the daw. Always recording.

Sometimes melody first. But mostly drums first.

Build an instrumental just chasing intuition, quickly. 2-3 melody parts and a bass line on top of drums. And youve got a chorus loop. 

Then take that improvisational melody muscle and apply it to the vocal melody. 

Im not a big humming guy, I get to words pretty quickly. But will start with common phrases to me like,  "runnin runnin runnin round runnin runnin runnin down" I have a few others.

I start to land on a melody, with a feeling and story. That I haven't told. Sometimes it takes 90 seconds, sometimes 5-10 mins. 

Record and comp till I have what I like. Than do all the background vocals. 

Then start muting a couple of the melody parts. Find my verses.

Rinse repeat the process above. But now I know the story and I just have to find the melody and the thru line narrative.

Depending on how the verses feel running into the chorus. Or short length of track. I'll write a bridge 

Melodyne the vocals.

Structure the song.

Mix the song.

Upload the song.

Make another.

This usually takes 2-4 days, intermittent with regular life.

author: Zack Hames
content:
1. Write a song every day (or attempt) certainly you’ve heard of and likely tried this, but nothing beats reps.

2. More technically, write out the structure (intro, verse, chorus, etc) of some of your favorite songs and mimic it exactly. Even as far as how many measures, or even dynamics (or tempo changes!)

3. If you play an instrument, Learn “great” songs. And ideally sing with them. Playing the best songs in the world will seep into your writing and show you new ideas on chord movements, melodies, and the physicality of a great song.

author: Yago Ibars
content: I've been having a thought on my songwriting I wanted to share here. As a songwriter I have this toolbox of melodic and harmonic approaches  that I can use to solve any problem when making a song, or to have direction to create another section. But recently I've been noticing that something that makes a huge impact on songs is how the different sections relate to the tempo of the track. I think this might not happen to people who write to a beat, but I think that when you are playing an instrument, tempo is so fluid that some parts of a song might "feel" good and others won't (at a same tempo). When all the sections flow well into another in terms of tempo (and probably how that affects to vocal delivery) it sucks you in as a listener and it is way more singable/enjoyable. And now I'm starting to see this as a priority more than which notes of the scale have more weight on the chorus and stuff like that.

author: Deleted User
content: I think a lot of it has to do with the melodic rhythm. In terms of how the sections flow, if the melody can drive it on its own- the accompaniment or production will follow. And as you mentioned, high notes can move the energy and accent the rhythm. Lyrical stress patterns could contribute to the accenting and note selections. Weight sometimes means notes that are held longer than the other sometimes the opposite. Contrasts can do a lot though. Range of movement or the range of the pitches themselves, pacing of the rhythm and rests, breaking the patterns/repetition can help with contrast

author: Yago Ibars
content: Couldn't agree more! I think what I was trying to say is that melodic rhythm is very much related to the tempo of the song and the delivery of the singer. And when tempo changes, even if the ratio remains the same, it has a different impact on how it feels. And, sometimes, because you might not be writing to a click, different sections of a song might "feel" cohesive at different tempos. And when you sum everything up it just doesn't translate well. And I've had the experience of trying to work around it but ended up noticing that it didn't have to do with the melodic rhythm in each section, but how it relates to the whole song. And now I try to be more aware of it because I think it might be something that is not easily noticeable when you are writing. I don't know if that makes sense (I'm not a native english speaker and therefore I struggle a bit sometimes 😆 ).

author: Yago Ibars
content: In my experience the sweet spot is somewhere in between both, as you guys have said. Melodically I tend to be like @Rob Domos and make everything as simple and predictable as possible, but sometimes it feels too easy and there is nothing that stands out. Lately my approach has been to use lyrics and chords to spice things up. For example, If I've got an idea for a lyric that I like, most times the metrics of it won't be incredibly predictable, and when I come up with a melody for it will be a bit more interesting than if I started out with the melody. Maybe then, for another section of the song I'll start with the melody and it'll be simpler. I think contrast is key. It really is an interesting topic!

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I go off the assumption that this is the only time I'll have this artist focused on this idea, so my priority is always getting a finished lead vocal and some ad libs. Those are the only things that can't be done without the artist there. I'll get the production together as much as it needs to be to get the artist excited about the song. 

The challenge is doing this quickly, without spending unnecessary time going through snares and patches and shit. I find that nearly all of the best songs I've written happen in about an hour long window of excitement. Sometimes you can stretch and get harmonies or punch in some vocals beyond that hour, but the excitement of a great idea is exhausting and it's hard to keep everyone 100% engaged for a long period of time. If I'm on hour 2 of a song and we're still trying to decide if we like a chorus, 100% of the time it's not a good song (in my experience).

A BIG mistake I make (still) is "oh we have tomorrow we can take a break and come back." It's not about being able to get the artist physically back, but getting everyone back into the emotional space. So much of what I need from an artist is the emotional focused to commit 100% to a vocal.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Do the songwriters get paid to create those demos?  No...  but they often PAY OTHERS to help them make the demo possible.  Nashville folk will often have "Demo Days" where a group of Ace players charge a flat fee to perform and record the rhythm section (for instance, could be anything the song needs). They might record 5-10 tracks in a day. I'm sure some have done more. These "demo day tracks" are used by songwriters to then pitch their track to recording artists, labels, anyone.  There's also a whole army of producers ready to help songwriters demo-up...  where the songwriter pays a producer to turnkey the track.  Sometimes it's one guy playing everything or a few remote players all chipping in under the producers direction.  

And...  these are viewed as a "very basic demo" in the eyes of industry vets. A really good "one take" by great players with high quality equipment recording the basic tracks is a strong demo but not fully produced. Happens all the time, but the producer (and their team) gets paid by the songwriter (or their team) to produce the track.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Great stuff above, my experience is a bit different, as I’m sure everyone’s is :)

I find that lyrics is where I get stuck, especially if I’m trying to write to a set melody. The biggest unlock for me was to write an entire song’s lyrics first, sometimes preceded with some journaling and/or research on the topic so I have real, meaningful things to draw from. I keep track of syllables etc so it lines up.

Once the lyrics are done and I’m working on the song, I always end up having to change a lot, usually simplify and take out, but it’s an easy problem when you have excess good lyrical content. As opposed to trying to summon something meaningful to fit a certain melody.

Simple stuff like starting with getting the chorus right has also been super helpful, and keeping production to a minimum before the topline is finished.

Excited to read more people’s hacks here

author: oaklandmatt
content:
The short answer is: you're a songwriter now too. This is a new part of your professional repertoire. This is great.

I made a similar transition from producing bands to doing co-writing sessions as a producer. You can still get hired as a producer or engineer (as I still do), but writing sessions are structured with different expectations and potential outcomes. 

When you participate in songwriting sessions, you are almost never getting paid up front as an engineer or producer. There are some cases where super rich people will pay for songwriting sessions, or artist with bigger budgets might get their label to pay a studio fee, but this will be a tiny minority of your writing sessions. 

Philosophically, the idea is that you're all creating something together that, if it's good enough, it will be released into the world in someway. But your experimenting and will make many ideas that don't cross that threshold. However, if any of the recordings of these song come out you will still get paid as a producer (/ engineer / mixer / whatever else you do on the final version). If no peace of the recording that you made when the song was written gets used, you will still participate as a songwriter on the copyright.

author: revolution
content:
i guess other forms of art like film or books often do require a lot of structure and thought in order to cohesively convey or execute a vision... even if the vision is fundamentally grounded on a seed of feeling or very specific idea. songs and music are so temporal and intuitive that it doesnt really require that necessarily. 

for better and worse, i tend to have this desire to seek out a 'scientific' nature in things. for me as a fan of films, i can often decipher or intuit the internal logic and intentionality that choreographs lights and angles and framing to create a moving feeling/painting. 

i do fully agree that fundamentally the only thing that can create this sense of 'spatial awareness' in a medium, or a sense of dialectic/causality between the subtle and intuitive, creative elements is experience and repetition; but i can't help but seek out knowledge or structure/self critique to my approach.

i think to that end, i should collaborate more with people who are experienced so i can accelerate my own learning if that's what i seek. i find myself always searching for this 'internal' awareness of intentionality, searching for the forces and patterns that make a system or experience exist and change how they do.

i am alwasy looking for this feeling of purpose or understanding of which steps are wanted/needed for me to take what ive created closer to its essence or my original vision. i think people understand this at the level of more technical creative aspects... for example mixing. ultimately the art is still to have a creative vision and executing that, but it's the experience and awareness to have intentionality and wisdom in how to execute that separates raw creativity/talent from a professional level of execution no? I think the same can be applied to more abstract skills like writing/songwriting.

i'm going to commit to writing new material everyday for a month and see what happens!
